column1: People define 'Open Science' in many ways, and it is a multi-faceted concept. We are interested in how you define Open Science, especially as it pertains to your own work. Please take a minute to share these thoughts. The more detailed, the better.

column1: For me, Open Science is 1) scientific data and results open for all the scientific community, without obligation to pay subscription fee for the journal of pay for particular scientific article (I am scientist/biologist in a poor country or country with low interest for science and ecology, whatever authorities would say) and (not mutually exclusive) 2) scientific data and results "translated" to common people, to overall community.
column13:
First, fees that should be payed for publishing in some Open Access journals. There are, however, other OA journals completely fee of charge, but they are often of low impact factor. 

Second, I cannot put my data to be open access immediately  after being collected because me and my students must use them for publishing scientific papers which will justify the funds we got from the funding source. However, many scientific journals, after accepting your paper, require original data of the study to be deposit in some of open access data bases.
column14: When stared to think about climate change in my surroundings, it was difficult to get meteorological data because state agency asked to be payed for the data formation and export. Then, a US colleague found review paper with 50 authors where some were from my home country. They had to deposit in the journal data base a 50 years of meteorological data exactly from the locality we needed. So, thanks to that highly impacted open access peer reviewed journal, we found and used the data we needed so badly.
column15: As I mentioned, as a scientist from a country with low incomes in science, and even simple field work requires funding, I am more and more aware that must turn to use of accessible (free of charge) online ecological data bases.
column27: I am not familiar with the code sharing so I skipped this answer.

column1:
I don't have a succinct or thought out definition of open science. In my mind, two core concepts are relevant, 1) that the science is open for access, also by non-professionals that don't have traditional access to papers through a research institutions subscription, and 2) that the science is open to scrutiny, which in most cases requires access to data or mock data and a sufficiently detailed description of the analysis steps, which in most cases means analysis scripts. Both these aspects should theoretically be satisfied in "traditional science", but often is not, or is unfeasible in practice. Open science seems to have a lot to do with easing these two types of "access".

I'm sure there are other facets to the term. Maybe this will clear up after the workshop.
column12: "Use open code" is ambiguous. Open source software in general or analysis algorithms authored by researchers?    Don't know what open education tools are. I use open software every day. I prefer to use it whenever I can.    I have access to most journals through work, so I'm not aware of when I read open papers.
column13:
It requires extra work, setting up the data access and tidying up scripts and writing documentation.

Hard to push as a co-author. My effort is to do it as a lead author or lead analysist.

It's a phycological barrier to reveal all the messiness behind the curtains.
column14: Practice in coding and choosing to use open source software. Routinely using Git. Getting (more and more) into the habit of writing scripts so that they could be read by anyone. That one is important. Learning how to write R-packages.
column15: I (think) I agree with the philosophy behind the theme, and would like to improve and streamline the process.
column27:
The research is probably not reproduced exactly as it was first performed as often as you'd think.

I've worked on datasets that have been to large to share, or not possible to share due to rights issues. You could create perhaps smaller fake datasets that lets anyone run through the steps of the analysis, without reproducing it exactly. 

Sometimes we also work in databases where it's not so easy to share data and code. Well, that's not true. I guess I'm just not used to it. I guess you could in principle share a database dump and database scripts.

column1:
• Publishing Open Access
  • Sharing published data and/or raw data in open repositories
  • Sharing code

These are the most important parts of open science to me and my research. However, I am aware that under the umbrella also open peer-review processes, open research funding processes, sharing laboratory journals, methods etc is becoming more important, to make the research process more transparent.
column13: It is a slow transition to get other researchers in collaboration to choose OA journals over subscription journals, and to share datasets in open repositories. Also, time and funding is limited, so extra activity to do so is often not prioritized. Infrastructure is also limited or lacking, sharing data in e.g. NSD is useless if there is no standard metadata format and no requirement to follow protocols.
column14: Knowing more about it through activities at the University libraries!
column15: I need to know more to be able to do research support in this area. Also, working on my own ecology dataset at the moment, this is a good opportunity to do both.
column27: I think all of the above is important both to allow me to do good research, but also important for me personally to take part in with my research. I am lucky to have access to all the literature I need, open or not, so OA published papers are not that important for me to be able to do my own research. It is however much more important for me to publish my own research openly, both to increase its impact and to be of benefit to researchers that are not this lucky to have University libraries with the coverage that we have in Norway.
column35: Difficult to answer, because part of my teaching is to encourage other researchers and students to contribute to and use open research, so in that sense it is extremely important (or there would not be teaching...). But in the regular biology courses this is less important for the curriculum I have

column1: The sharing of scientific theory, data and results such that it can be accessed by anyone, and properly credited to those responsible for its creation.
column13: Early stage of my career, limited opportunities for publishing of data and manuscripts.
column14: Encouragement of supervisors and colleagues, intuitive open source tools.
column15: Networking opportunities and the chance to learn more about an issue that Norway thankfully seems to take very seriously.

column1:
Open, immediate, royalty-free access to:

  • Publications
  • Data
  • Source code

open science != FAIR science
column13:
• patenting considerations
  • PI concerns
  • lack of collaboration in projects on open science
column14:
• open access publication funds
  • established data deposition databases and sharing culture
column15: Gaining insights in FAIR DM in ecological research in Norway

column1: Open science is research and knowledge that is available to everyone, regardless of social or economic situation. Open science also includes access to data, where individual privacy, consent and security is paramount, transparency and replicability of methods and the use of data in these methods.
column15: Wanted to learn more about Living Norway and see how our organisation can contribute to its development.

column1: Scienctific publications and the data used (can be anonymised) should easily without costs be accessible through internet.
column13: Nothing actually but the understanding of what can be shared and not is not always easy to understand and therefore it is sometimes a bit problematic to publish total open as there might bbe constraints concerning the data used.
column14: My nearest collegue/ neighbour office at work.
column15: It was offered and as I'm engaged at work to be one of the persons that should have some more knowledge than others I think I need more input.

column1: transparency and reproducibility of research methods, adaptability of research methods and data for different purposes, access to knowledge and scientific processes.
column13: Feeling inadequate in terms of coding ability - and being inadequate in coding ability (e.g. not knowing how to use github, and many of the resources I found to learn were written by geeks and not so intelligible, similarly it taking a few attempts before I could successfully build an R package). Also cost - for open access publishing. But mostly time - time to learn how to do things, learn about new databases, the extra time it takes to write metadata and document code properly.
column14: Online resources that are well written for relative beginners. User friendly platforms (e.g. OSF) that allow integration of multiple people from multiple institutions, and multiple types of files.
column15: I think I was coerced by my supervisor... and the opportunity to learn new tools and techniques in-person.
column27: I mostly work on trade-offs in environmental spheres, so this means potential conflict arenas. I need lots of data from different sources, many different modelling techniques, and I need my methods to be transparent and reproducible, to give validity to my modelling.

column1: I would define Open Science, in the immediate sense, as a way of conducting research in a manner that is transparent (i.e. showcasing/sharing how you are doing your research), however this should extend past just sharing your research and it should also include creating and cultivating a research environment that is open and inclusive to all. Within my work the aspect of reproducibility (particularly code-sharing) is something that I place particular value on
column13: Awareness of the concept/spaces/platforms that are available and facilitate cultivating an 'open' research workflow. In addition to this collaborating with colleagues that are 'hesitant' to engage with some of the platforms available sometimes disrupts the intended workflow.
column14: Being involved in a course that implemented (and showcased) various elements of a 'Open Science' workflow, this helped foster an understanding and appreciation of Open Science. In addition, working in a lab that has an active Open Science policy means that it is expected (and facilitated) that my work be conducted in a manner that aligns with FAIR and Open Science principles
column15: Although I am enthusiastic about Open Science I feel like there are elements/tools that I am not yet familiar with and believe that this workshop will help highlight/showcase some new approaches to OS both as a learning tool but also as a potential teaching tool in the future.
column27: If I could I would have put everything under 'Extremely important' but there are some things I value a bit more than others ;-)

column1: I do not really have a definition. but in my understanding/interpretation/subjective perception open science is transparant and accessible. Open science I can find and access, and I can see where it comes from i.e. how the poeice of science has developed and been produced.
column13:
sharing data can be an issue - need time to document sufficiently so it's useful for others, also like to "control" access/use of data in terms of wanting to be of help when starting to work with data so can provide support for approriate handling and interpretation (not all intricacies of the data set can be easily explained in the metadata),

open access publishing fees could be an issue (depending on current funding)
column15: partly work related - I work at a biodiversity infrastaructure with largely open data and trying top adhere to FAIR, I have also been at the previous LivingNorway coloquium, but I am also gennerally interested in accessible science and supporting students in data management and open science

column1: Open science for me is being as transparent as possible about the scientific process, from conception of the study to completion. It involves communicating the results and methods in a standard format but more than that it also includes all resources and information required to repeat the analyses (e.g. data and code). To be truly open, resources should be provided in the most easily usable and clear way with appropriate documentation.
column13: Knowledge of best practice. Sometimes also journal restrictions, I am not always clear when I can make resources freely available and still publish in a journal.
column15: Interested to learn more about how to make my work more transparent.
column27: All science should be as open as possible and communicated as clearly as possible. On top of the above, we should always think about the audience we are communicating to.
column35: I'm not sure I fully understood this question. Should it be 'how important are these to teach?' or 'do we use them in teaching?'. Ultimately, I teach statistics and think all of these topics are important to cover and mention (maybe papers less), but we don't use many open resources.

column1:
- open sharing of data according to FAIR standards

- sharing of code/analyses/methodology

- open access (nothing behind paywalls)

- use of non-proprietary software/equipment

- transparency from start to end of project, e.g. preregistration

- more effective, equitable, complete synthesis of research
column12: For many of these, I answered "Rarely" because I do the activity as a whole rarely, not because I've used open science practices a small proportion of the times I've done the activity. For example, I've shared the data for all papers I've published so far, but at this career stage I've only averaged 1 paper/year--so I had to select "rarely" even though it's been my normal practice every time I've published.
column13:
- lack of familiarity with relevant online platforms, software, methods

- perception that the landscape of the above tools changes very quickly, and keeping up is a big time commitment

- fear of doing it wrong
column14:
- discussions among supervisors and colleagues

- training in relevant tools and methods

- journal requirements

- increasing perception that it is good for career development/CV/funding
column15: - learn more about current best practices in data sharing and integration

column1: I would define Open Science as science in which all stages are transparent. I.e. the data itself is openly accessible to anyone, the methods used for analysing/interpreting the data are described/published in a way that makes them reproducible, and results are published as "Open Access" (or in other was that makes them accessible to anyone)
column13: I have yet to be directly hindered. Potentially by time limitation
column14: My institution encourages publishing in Open Access journals by covering publication fees
column15: A general interest in Open Science, future career paths, relevance to current research

column1:
Open Science is about responsible, transparent, reproducible and accessible research and knowledge.

It has several different aspects and applications, as Open Acces, Open data, Research Data Management/FAIR data, Open Source, Open Education, Citizen Science, Open Innovation.

Open Science is also science and research that is collaborative, engaging and inclusive, and reinforcing best practices, mentoring  and support as a a natural part of science. Finally, Open Science  is also about new tools and possibilites in a digital word.

Open Science = Science done right

Open science means in my opinion open Access to the data behind any science study or Project. Openness will Ensure transparency of the Scientific work itself and will create more science possibilities and further use of data.
Data and research that it is openly available and findable for everyone
